name: % Transferrin Saturation
description: Percentage of transferrin iron‑binding sites that are occupied by iron.
details: Transferrin saturation is calculated as (serum iron ÷ total iron‐binding capacity) × 100 and is used to assess iron status; values <20% suggest deficiency and >50% suggest overload.

name: 17-hydroxyprogesterone
description: A steroid hormone produced by the adrenal cortex and gonads; a precursor in the biosynthesis of cortisol and androgenic steroids.
details: Used primarily to screen for congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH) due to 21-hydroxylase deficiency; levels vary by age, sex, and menstrual cycle phase.

name: Aldosterone
description: A steroid hormone produced by the zona glomerulosa of the adrenal cortex; regulates sodium and potassium balance.
details: Measured in serum or plasma; interpretation depends on patient position and concurrent renin measurement; elevated aldosterone with low renin suggests primary hyperaldosteronism.

name: Alkaline Phosphatase
description: An enzyme that hydrolyzes phosphate esters at alkaline pH, produced by liver (especially bile canaliculi), bone (osteoblasts), kidney, and intestine.
details: Used primarily to assess hepatobiliary and bone disorders; elevated in cholestatic liver disease, bone growth, or metastases; low levels may indicate malnutrition or hypothyroidism.

name: Alpha Feto Protein (AFP)
description: A glycoprotein produced by the fetal yolk sac and liver, used as a tumor marker in adults and for prenatal screening of neural tube defects.
details: In adults, elevated AFP levels suggest hepatocellular carcinoma or non-seminomatous germ cell tumors; in pregnancy, measured between 15–21 weeks gestation to screen for neural tube defects and chromosomal abnormalities.

name: Aluminium
description: Aluminium is a widely distributed metal in the environment that is poorly absorbed from the gut; under normal renal function, serum aluminium is efficiently excreted by the kidneys.
details: Serum aluminium levels <15 µg/L are considered normal; levels up to 50 µg/L may occur in patients on chronic dialysis; levels above 100 µg/L are associated with symptoms of aluminium toxicity such as bone disease and neurotoxicity.

name: Androstenedione
description: A C19 steroid hormone produced by the adrenal glands and gonads; serves as a precursor to testosterone and oestrogens.
details: Reference ranges vary by age and sex: adult female (pre-menopause) 0.9–7.5 nmol/L; adult female (post-menopause) 0.4–2.9 nmol/L; adult male (18–40 yrs) 1.1–5.6 nmol/L; adult male (41–67 yrs) 0.8–4.7 nmol/L; neonatal and paediatric values depend on Tanner stage.

name: Anti -Chlamydia antibody IgG
description: Serological detection of IgG antibodies against Chlamydia trachomatis, indicating past or chronic infection.
details: Titers <1:64 are considered negative; a single titer ≥1:64 suggests past or chronic infection; titers ≥1:512 indicate current or recent infection; cross-reactivity with other Chlamydia species can occur.

name: Anti -Chlamydia antibody IgM
description: Serological detection of IgM antibodies against Chlamydia trachomatis, indicating recent or current infection.
details: Titers <1:20 are considered negative; titers ≥1:20 suggest recent or active infection; higher titers (≥1:80) indicate stronger immune response and ongoing infection; cross-reactivity with other Chlamydia species may occur.

name: Anti Cyclic Citrullinated Peptide Antibody (ACCP)
description: Autoantibodies directed against citrullinated peptides; highly specific markers for rheumatoid arthritis.
details: Results are reported as: <20 U/mL negative; 20–39 U/mL weakly positive; 40–59 U/mL moderately positive; ≥60 U/mL strongly positive. Anti-CCP has ~94-99% specificity and 61-75% sensitivity for RA.

name: Anti Streptolysin-O (ASO)
description: Measures antibodies against streptolysin O, a toxin produced by Streptococcus bacteria; indicates recent or past streptococcal infection.
details: Normal adult levels are <200 U/mL; pediatric normals are <150 U/mL. Titers 200–400 U/mL are equivocal and may require repeat testing; >400 U/mL strongly suggests recent infection. Antibody levels rise 1–3 weeks post-infection, peak at 3–5 weeks, and decline over ~6 months.

name: Anti Thyroglobulin Antibody (ATG)
description: Autoantibodies directed against thyroglobulin; used to detect autoimmune thyroid disorders (e.g., Hashimoto's thyroiditis, Graves' disease) and to monitor thyroid cancer recurrence.
details: Normal levels are generally <4 IU/mL; levels between 5–20 IU/mL are considered borderline/equivocal and may warrant monitoring; levels >20 IU/mL indicate significant autoimmunity. In thyroid cancer follow-up, rising TgAb may signal recurrence. Assay methods and reference ranges vary by laboratory.

name: Anti- Hepatitis A virus
description: Serological detection of IgM antibodies against hepatitis A virus (HAV) for diagnosis of acute infection.
details: Results are reported as index values: <0.90 negative; 0.90–<1.10 equivocal (gray zone); ≥1.10 positive, indicating acute or recent HAV infection. False positives/negatives can occur, especially with biotin interference or immunocompromise.

name: Anti-Hepatitis C virus (Anti HCV) Total
description: Serological detection of total antibodies against hepatitis C virus; used as an initial screening test to determine exposure, requiring confirmatory HCV RNA testing for active infection.
details: Results are reported as index values: ≤0.79 negative; 0.80–0.99 equivocal (gray zone, repeat testing recommended); 1.00–10.99 low positive; ≥11.00 high positive (strongly suggestive of past or current infection). All reactive or equivocal results should be reflexed to HCV RNA NAT to confirm active infection.

name: Antimony
description: Antimony is a nonessential metalloid in humans that reflects environmental or occupational exposure; serum levels are monitored to assess body burden and potential toxicity.
details: Healthy individuals typically have serum antimony levels between 1–3 µg/L; levels above 6 µg/L may indicate significant exposure and warrant further evaluation, while levels exceeding 20 µg/L are associated with clinical symptoms of antimony toxicity (e.g., gastrointestinal, cardiac, respiratory effects).

name: Antinuclear Antibodies (ANA)
description: Autoantibodies against various nuclear antigens; screened by indirect immunofluorescence, used in diagnosis of systemic autoimmune rheumatic diseases (e.g., lupus, scleroderma).
details: Reported as titers: <1:40 negative; 1:40–1:80 low positive (often nonspecific); ≥1:160 clinically significant for autoimmune disease; patterns (homogeneous, speckled, nucleolar) guide further antigen-specific testing.

name: Apo B/Apo A1 ratio
description: Balance between atherogenic Apo B–containing lipoproteins and protective Apo A1 in HDL; higher ratios indicate greater cardiovascular disease risk.
details: Ratios ≤0.77 in men and ≤0.63 in women are optimal; moderate risk is 0.77–0.95 for men and 0.63–0.78 for women; high risk is >0.95 (men) and >0.78 (women). Based on ESC/EAS guidelines and the AMORIS study.

name: Apolipoprotein-A1
description: Apolipoprotein A1 is the primary protein component of high-density lipoprotein (HDL), essential for reverse cholesterol transport and inversely associated with cardiovascular disease risk.
details: ApoA1 constitutes ~70% of HDL protein, promotes cholesterol efflux to the liver, and low levels correlate with higher coronary artery disease risk; mutations in APOA1 can cause Tangier disease.

name: Apolipoprotein-B
description: Primary apolipoprotein of LDL and VLDL particles; essential for lipid transport and directly associated with atherogenic risk.
details: ApoB levels reflect the number of atherogenic lipoprotein particles. Optimal targets are <100 mg/dL for general population, <80 mg/dL for high-risk patients; levels >130 mg/dL indicate increased cardiovascular risk. Levels above 400 mg/dL are uncommon and suggest severe dyslipidemia.

name: Appearance
description: Visual assessment of urine clarity and color as part of a routine urinalysis to detect abnormalities.
details: Reported descriptors include clear, slightly cloudy, cloudy, turbidity (turbid), or opaque. Clear urine is normal; cloudiness may indicate infection, high cell counts, or presence of crystals.

name: Arsenic
description: A metalloid whose blood levels reflect recent environmental or occupational exposure; used to detect acute poisoning or assess exposure risk.
details: Typical blood arsenic in healthy individuals is ≤10 µg/L; levels 10–50 µg/L may indicate moderate exposure; levels 50–600 µg/L suggest significant acute exposure and require medical evaluation; >600 µg/L is associated with severe toxicity.

name: Average Blood Glucose
description: Estimated average blood glucose (eAG) over the past 2–3 months, derived from Hemoglobin A1c or continuous glucose monitoring to reflect mean daily glycemia.
details: eAG is calculated from HbA1c using the formula eAG = (28.7 × A1c) – 46.7 to translate percentage A1c into mg/dL values; Standard ranges per OptimalDX are 82–154 mg/dL and the ideal target range is 85–105 mg/dL for good glycemic control.

name: Bacteria
description: Microscopic count of bacteria per high-power field in urine, indicating the presence of infection or contamination.
details: No bacteria per HPF is normal; 1–10 bacteria/HPF suggests possible low-level contamination or early infection; >10 bacteria/HPF indicates significant bacteriuria consistent with urinary tract infection.

name: Barium
description: Barium is a non-essential element measured in blood to evaluate environmental or occupational exposure; elevated levels can cause cardiovascular and gastrointestinal toxicity.
details: Normal blood barium concentrations are typically <10 µg/L; levels between 10–50 µg/L suggest moderate exposure, while levels >50 µg/L warrant evaluation for potential toxicity; levels up to 400 µg/L have been reported in acute poisoning cases.

name: Basophils
description: The percentage of basophils among total white blood cells, part of the differential count to assess immune response and detect hematologic abnormalities.
details: Normal basophil percentage is 0–1% of total WBCs and absolute count 0–100 cells/µL; levels >1% up to 3% are moderate (basophilia), while >3% or >300 cells/µL strongly suggests hematologic disorders or severe allergy responses.

name: Basophils - absolute count
description: Absolute number of basophils per microliter of blood, used alongside the percentage differential to assess for basophilia or basopenia.
details: Normal absolute basophil count is 0–100 cells/µL; counts between 101–300 cells/µL represent moderate basophilia; counts above 300 cells/µL are strongly suggestive of significant hematologic disorders or severe allergic/inflammatory responses. Values should be interpreted in context with clinical findings and other differential counts.

name: Beryllium
description: Beryllium is a lightweight metal monitored in blood to detect environmental or occupational exposure; elevated levels can lead to lung disease and berylliosis.
details: Normal blood beryllium in the general population is ≤0.42 µg/L; levels between 0.43–1.0 µg/L suggest low-to-moderate exposure, while levels >1.0 µg/L indicate significant exposure requiring medical evaluation. Long-term elevated levels are associated with chronic beryllium disease (berylliosis).

name: Beta HCG
description: Quantitative measure of the beta subunit of human chorionic gonadotropin in serum, used for pregnancy detection and monitoring of trophoblastic diseases.
details: In non-pregnant individuals, levels should be ≤5 IU/L; levels between 5–25 IU/L constitute a gray zone requiring repeat testing; levels ≥25 IU/L confirm pregnancy. Serum hCG roughly doubles every 48 hours in early gestation and peaks around 10 weeks of gestation.

name: Bile pigment
description: Qualitative detection of bile pigments (conjugated bilirubin) in urine, indicating cholestasis or hepatic dysfunction.
details: Normally absent in urine; a positive result (bilirubinuria) suggests obstructive jaundice or liver cell damage. Follow-up with serum bilirubin and liver function tests is recommended.

name: Bile salt
description: Qualitative detection of bile salts in urine, indicating cholestasis or hepatic dysfunction.
details: Normally absent in urine; a positive result suggests the presence of conjugated bilirubin due to obstructive jaundice or hepatocellular damage.

name: Bilirubin - Indirect
description: Conjugated-unbound (unconjugated) bilirubin produced from heme breakdown, bound to albumin and transported to the liver for conjugation.
details: Calculated as total bilirubin minus direct bilirubin; elevated indirect bilirubin indicates increased production (hemolysis) or impaired hepatic conjugation (e.g., Gilbert syndrome).

name: Bilirubin - Total
description: Total bilirubin is the sum of unconjugated (indirect) and conjugated (direct) bilirubin in serum, reflecting hepatic uptake, conjugation, and excretion functions.
details: Elevated total bilirubin may indicate hemolysis, hepatic dysfunction, or bile duct obstruction; levels 1.3–2.0 mg/dL are mildly elevated, whereas >2.0 mg/dL is clinically significant and may present with jaundice. Trends and fractionation (direct vs indirect) guide diagnosis.

name: Bilirubin - Direct
description: Conjugated (direct) bilirubin that has been processed by the liver and made water-soluble for excretion in bile.
details: Elevated direct bilirubin may indicate biliary obstruction, cholestasis, or hepatocellular injury; direct bilirubin levels >0.3 mg/dL warrant further evaluation with imaging and liver panel tests.

name: Blood Ketone (D3HB)
description: Quantitative measurement of D-3-hydroxybutyrate (BOHB) in blood, the predominant ketone body produced during ketogenesis.
details: Normal fasting beta-hydroxybutyrate concentrations are <0.6 mmol/L ([gloshospitals.nhs.uk](https://www.gloshospitals.nhs.uk/our-services/services-we-offer/pathology/tests-and-investigations/beta-hydroxybutyrate-bohb/?utm_source=chatgpt.com)); levels 0.6–1.0 mmol/L suggest nutritional ketosis ([leedsth.nhs.uk](https://www.leedsth.nhs.uk/services/pathology/tests/free-fatty-acids-ffa-%CE%B2-hydroxybutyrate-d3hb/?utm_source=chatgpt.com)); levels 1.0–2.9 mmol/L indicate metabolic decompensation (early DKA) ([pathology.uhsussex.nhs.uk](https://pathology.uhsussex.nhs.uk/pug/?catid=10&id=202&view=article&utm_source=chatgpt.com)); levels ≥3.0 mmol/L denote severe ketoacidosis ([pathology.uhsussex.nhs.uk](https://pathology.uhsussex.nhs.uk/pug/?catid=10&id=202&view=article&utm_source=chatgpt.com)).

name: Blood Urea Nitrogen (BUN)
description: Measurement of urea nitrogen in blood, reflecting renal excretory function and protein metabolism.
details: Normal BUN values in adults range from 6–24 mg/dL per Mayo Clinic and 8–20 mg/dL per Medscape; elevated levels may indicate impaired renal function, dehydration, high-protein diet, or catabolic states; low levels may occur in liver disease or overhydration. Pediatric ranges are lower (infants and children 5–18 mg/dL); critical values >100 mg/dL suggest severe renal impairment.

name: Bismuth
description: A heavy metal monitored in blood to assess environmental, occupational, or therapeutic exposure; elevated levels may cause gastrointestinal, neurological, or renal toxicity.
details: Normal whole blood bismuth levels are ≤5.0 µg/L per ARUP Laboratories; levels between 5–50 µg/L may reflect low-to-moderate exposure or contamination; levels ≥50 µg/L are associated with clinical toxicity such as encephalopathy and renal dysfunction. Confirmation in a metal-free tube is recommended for elevated results.

name: BUN/Serum Creatinine Ratio
description: Ratio of blood urea nitrogen to serum creatinine, used to differentiate prerenal azotemia from other causes of renal dysfunction.
details: A BUN/Creatinine ratio of 10–20:1 is normal; a ratio >20:1 suggests prerenal azotemia (e.g., dehydration, hypoperfusion); a ratio <10:1 may indicate intrinsic renal injury or low protein intake.

name: C-Peptide
description: C-Peptide is released in equimolar amounts to insulin from pancreatic β-cells and serves as a marker of endogenous insulin production.
details: Measured via immunoassay, fasting C-Peptide levels reflect basal insulin secretion. Post-prandial and stimulated levels help distinguish between type 1 and type 2 diabetes, insulinoma, and assess β-cell function in insulin-treated patients.

name: CA 125
description: Cancer antigen 125 is a glycoprotein used primarily to monitor epithelial ovarian cancer activity and response to therapy.
details: Serum CA 125 concentrations ≤35 U/mL are considered within normal limits; elevations above this threshold can occur in ovarian cancer, but also in benign gynecologic conditions. Serial measurements are used to assess treatment response and detect recurrence.

name: CA 15.3
description: Cancer antigen 15-3 is a mucin-type glycoprotein commonly elevated in breast cancer and used to monitor treatment response and detect recurrence.
details: Normal serum CA 15-3 levels are ≤30 U/mL. Elevated CA 15-3 levels can occur in metastatic breast cancer, with moderate elevations (31–50 U/mL) suggesting possible disease activity and levels ≥51 U/mL indicating significant tumor burden; serial measurements are used to assess therapy efficacy and disease progression.

name: CA 19.9
description: Cancer antigen 19-9 is a carbohydrate antigen used to monitor pancreatic, biliary, and gastrointestinal malignancies, as well as certain benign hepatobiliary conditions.
details: Serum CA 19-9 levels ≤37 U/mL are considered within the reference range; levels between 38–100 U/mL are moderately elevated and may reflect benign conditions or early malignancy; levels ≥101 U/mL suggest significant tumor burden. CA 19-9 is commonly used in pancreatic cancer surveillance, but may rise in cholangitis, cirrhosis, and other GI diseases.

name: Calcium
description: Total serum calcium including bound and free (ionized) forms; essential for bone health, neuromuscular function, and cellular signaling.
details: Total calcium consists of ~50% albumin-bound, ~10% complexed, and ~40% ionized. Levels <8.5 mg/dL indicate hypocalcemia risk (e.g., neuromuscular excitability), while >10.2 mg/dL suggests hypercalcemia (e.g., hyperparathyroidism, malignancy, vitamin D disorders). Ionized calcium (4.5–5.6 mg/dL) is the physiologically active fraction.

name: Cadmium
description: Cadmium is a toxic metal; blood levels primarily reflect recent exposure, with higher levels indicating increased risk of renal and other organ toxicity.
details: Normal whole blood cadmium levels are up to 1 µg/L in nonsmokers and up to 4 µg/L in smokers; levels around 10 µg/L have been associated with renal dysfunction and indicate significant exposure requiring evaluation.

name: Casts
description: Microscopic examination of urinary sediment for urinary casts, including hyaline, granular, cellular, and waxy casts, to assess renal tubular health.
details: No casts per low-power field (LPF) is normal; 1–2 hyaline casts/LPF may be seen in concentrated urine or after exercise; presence of granular, RBC, WBC, or waxy casts indicates underlying renal pathology such as tubular injury or inflammation.

name: Caesium
description: Cesium (Cs) is a non-essential alkali metal measured in blood to assess environmental or accidental exposure; levels correlate with external contamination and are excreted slowly via the kidneys.
details: Normal blood cesium concentrations are typically <1 µg/L; levels between 1.1–5 µg/L may reflect low to moderate environmental exposure; levels >5 µg/L require evaluation for potential acute contamination or toxicity. Cesium has a biological half-life of ~110 days in humans.

name: Carcino Embryonic Antigen (CEA)
description: CEA is a glycoprotein involved in cell adhesion; elevated levels are used to monitor colorectal and other cancers.
details: Normal CEA levels in non-smokers are ≤5 ng/mL (≤10 ng/mL in smokers); levels >10 ng/mL suggest malignancy or recurrence. Serial measurements are used to assess treatment response and detect relapse in colorectal, pancreatic, gastric, lung, and breast cancers.

name: Chromium
description: Chromium is an essential trace element involved in insulin function and glucose metabolism; measured in blood to assess nutritional status and excessive exposure.
details: Normal serum chromium levels range from 0.1–1.0 µg/L; levels above 1.0 µg/L may reflect environmental or occupational overexposure; levels above 5 µg/L require evaluation for potential toxicity, manifesting as dermatitis or renal impairment.

name: Cobalt
description: Cobalt is an essential trace element (a component of vitamin B12) but can accumulate with industrial or prosthetic exposure, with toxicity manifesting as cardiomyopathy, dermatitis, and pulmonary issues.
details: Measured by ICP-MS in serum/plasma. Normal serum/plasma levels run from 1.7–6.8 nmol/L (≈0.1–0.4 µg/L), while healthy whole-blood levels are ≤1.0 µg/L (ARUP). Levels up to 1.0 µg/L may reflect mild environmental or dietary exposure. Values above 5.0 µg/L warrant evaluation for prosthetic wear or industrial exposure :contentReference[oaicite:0]{index=0}.

name: Colour
description: Visual assessment of urine color using standard terminology to detect abnormalities.
details: Normal urine color ranges from pale yellow to amber due to urochrome pigment. Variations such as dark yellow/dehydration, red/pink (hematuria or porphyrins), brown/black (bilirubinuria or myoglobinuria), green/blue (dyes or rare metabolic conditions) warrant further investigation.

name: Copper
description: Serum copper is an essential trace element carried mainly by ceruloplasmin; measured to assess nutritional status, genetic disorders (e.g., Wilson’s, Menkes), and toxic exposures.
details: Adult serum copper reference ranges are 70–140 µg/dL (11–22 µmol/L); levels below 60 µg/dL may indicate deficiency (e.g., Menkes syndrome), while levels above 200 µg/dL suggest copper overload or toxicity. Infants (0–6 months): 20–70 µg/dL; children (6 years): 90–190 µg/dL; adolescents (12 years): 80–160 µg/dL; pregnancy (term): 118–302 µg/dL.

name: Cortisol
description: A glucocorticoid steroid hormone produced by the adrenal cortex; regulates metabolism, immune response, stress response, and circadian rhythm.
details: Total serum cortisol peaks in early morning (8 AM) and reaches its lowest levels late evening. Morning (8 AM) normal range is 5–23 µg/dL and afternoon (4 PM) is 3–13 µg/dL; levels <5 µg/dL at 8 AM suggest insufficiency, while levels >35 µg/dL may indicate stress response or Cushing's syndrome. Pregnancy increases cortisol: first trimester 7–19 µg/dL, second trimester 10–42 µg/dL, third trimester 12–50 µg/dL.

name: Corticosterone
description: A glucocorticoid precursor to aldosterone and cortisol produced by the adrenal cortex; used primarily in the diagnosis and monitoring of congenital adrenal hyperplasia and mineralocorticoid pathway disorders.
details: Reference values (Mayo Clinic): adults (>18 years) 53–1,560 ng/dL; children (≤18 years) 18–1,970 ng/dL. Elevated corticosterone occurs in 11β-hydroxylase deficiencies, CAH, glucocorticoid-responsive hyperaldosteronism, and other enzyme defects in the mineralocorticoid pathway. Specimen: morning (8 AM) serum via LC-MS/MS.

name: Creatinine - Urine
description: Concentration of creatinine in urine, used to assess renal function and to calculate creatinine clearance when paired with serum creatinine.
details: Normal random urine creatinine is 20–350 mg/dL; values <20 mg/dL may indicate dilute urine or low muscle mass; values >350 mg/dL suggest concentrated urine or impaired clearance. For 24-hour urine collection, normal excretion is 800–2000 mg/day.

name: C-reactive protein (HSCRP)
description: High-sensitivity C-reactive protein is an acute-phase protein produced by the liver in response to inflammation; measured to assess cardiovascular risk and low-grade chronic inflammation.
details: hs-CRP levels <1 mg/L indicate low cardiovascular risk; 1–3 mg/L indicate moderate risk; >3 mg/L indicate high risk for cardiovascular events. Levels >10 mg/L suggest acute inflammation or infection and warrant clinical evaluation.

name: Crystals
description: Qualitative identification of crystal type in urine sediment, indicating solute precipitation and potential metabolic or renal disorders.
details: Common urinary crystals include calcium oxalate (envelope-shaped), uric acid (yellow rhombic), triple phosphate (coffin lid), cystine (hexagonal), and others. Occasional few crystals may be normal in concentrated urine; abundant or unusual crystals can suggest urolithiasis, metabolic diseases, or renal tubular dysfunction.

name: Cystatin C
description: A low molecular weight protein produced by all nucleated cells and filtered freely by the glomeruli; a sensitive marker for estimating glomerular filtration rate independent of muscle mass.
details: Adult serum cystatin C reference ranges: 0.56–0.99 mg/L per Marshfield Labs ([marshfieldlabs.org](https://www.marshfieldlabs.org/sites/ltrm/Human/Pages/23230.aspx?utm_source=chatgpt.com)); 0.62–1.15 mg/L reported by SelfDecode ([labs.selfdecode.com](https://labs.selfdecode.com/blog/cystatin-c/?utm_source=chatgpt.com)). In neonates, first days of life range 1.64–2.59 mg/L, decreasing to 0.7–1.38 mg/L after 1 year ([link.springer.com](https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007/s004670050419?utm_source=chatgpt.com)). Elevated levels indicate impaired GFR and early kidney dysfunction.

name: Dehydroepiandrosterone
description: A weakly androgenic steroid produced primarily by the adrenal cortex; serves as a precursor to androgens and estrogens and is used to assess adrenal function in disorders like congenital adrenal hyperplasia and adrenal tumors.
details: Reference ranges vary by sex, menstrual phase, and age: adult male 147–1760 ng/dL; adult female mid-follicular 385–1143 ng/dL, mid-luteal 414–1295 ng/dL, surge 345–2030 ng/dL; post-menopausal 77–851 ng/dL; pediatric values increase with age from ≤327 ng/dL in infancy to ~1360 ng/dL by adolescence.

name: Deoxycortisol
description: Also known as 11-deoxycortisol or Compound S; a steroid hormone precursor in cortisol biosynthesis, measured to assess adrenal function and used in metyrapone testing.
details: Typical 8 AM serum reference ranges: adults (>18 yrs): 10–79 ng/dL; children (≤18 yrs): <344 ng/dL. In newborns and infants, ranges vary by gestational age and postnatal days: premature (26–28 wks, day 4): 110–1376 ng/dL; premature (31–35 wks, day 4): 48–579 ng/dL; full-term newborn (day 3): 13–147 ng/dL; 31 days–11 months: <10–156 ng/dL. Prepubertal (8 AM): 20–155 ng/dL; pubertal children & adults (8 AM): 12–158 ng/dL. After overnight metyrapone challenge, expected rise <1700 ng/dL.

name: DEXA Scan
description: Dual-energy X-ray absorptiometry (DEXA) scan to measure bone mineral density at standard sites such as lumbar spine, femoral neck, total hip, and forearm.
details: DEXA provides BMD in g/cm² and calculates T-scores (compares to young-adult reference) and Z-scores (age- and sex-matched). WHO criteria: T-score ≥ -1.0 is normal; between -1.0 and -2.5 indicates osteopenia; ≤ -2.5 diagnoses osteoporosis ([emedicine.medscape.com](https://emedicine.medscape.com/article/393602-overview?utm_source=chatgpt.com)). Recommended screening for postmenopausal women, men aged ≥70, and individuals at high fracture risk ([emedicine.medscape.com](https://emedicine.medscape.com/article/330598-guidelines?utm_source=chatgpt.com)).

name: DHEA - Sulphate (DHEAS)
description: A sulfated form of dehydroepiandrosterone produced by the adrenal cortex; serves as a marker of adrenal androgen production and used in evaluation of adrenal disorders.
details: Typical adult reference ranges: male 80–560 µg/dL; female 35–430 µg/dL. Levels vary with age, peaking in the third decade and declining thereafter. Elevated levels may indicate adrenal hyperplasia, adrenal tumors, or polycystic ovary syndrome; low levels suggest adrenal insufficiency or hypopituitarism.

name: Direct Renin
description: Quantitative measurement of plasma renin concentration by immunoassay, used to assess renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system activity in hypertension and adrenal disorders.
details: Reference ranges vary by posture: after supine rest, normal plasma direct renin is 4.2–60 mIU/L; after 30 min upright, 5.3–99 mIU/L. Values above these ranges may indicate renin hypersecretion (e.g., renal artery stenosis), and low values suggest primary hyperaldosteronism or hyporeninemia. Specimen: morning EDTA plasma after standardized posture.

name: Epigenetic Age Testing
description: Estimation of biological age based on genome-wide DNA methylation profiles using established epigenetic clocks.
details: Epigenetic clocks such as Horvath, Hannum, PhenoAge, and GrimAge predict biological age. The primary output—epigenetic age acceleration—is the difference between estimated and chronological age. Values within ±5 years suggest normal aging concordance; 6–10 years acceleration indicates moderate deviation; >10 years represents significant accelerated aging linked to elevated risks of morbidity and mortality. Technical error of measurement is approximately ±3 years.

name: Epithelial cells
description: Microscopic count of epithelial cells per high-power field in urine sediment, indicating cellular shedding from urinary tract lining.
details: Few epithelial cells (0–5/HPF) is normal; increased squamous cells suggest contamination; elevated transitional or renal tubular epithelial cells (≥6/HPF) may indicate inflammation, infection, or tubular injury.

name: Eosinophils
description: Percentage of eosinophils among total white blood cells, typically measured as part of the differential count to assess allergic and parasitic conditions.
details: Normal eosinophil percentage is 1–4% of total WBCs. Values 5–10% represent mild eosinophilia (seen in allergic disorders, parasitic infections); >10% indicates moderate to severe eosinophilia, warranting evaluation for hypereosinophilic syndromes or severe allergic/autoimmune diseases.

name: Eosinophils - absolute count
description: Eosinophils are a type of white blood cell that play roles in allergic reactions and combating parasitic infections.
details: Measured via complete blood count as the absolute number of eosinophils per microliter of blood. Elevated levels (>500 cells/µL) indicate eosinophilia, associated with allergies, parasitic infections, and certain hematologic disorders. Low levels (<30 cells/µL) may result from acute infections or corticosteroid therapy.

name: ESR
description: ESR (Erythrocyte Sedimentation Rate) measures how quickly red blood cells settle at the bottom of a test tube in one hour, reflecting levels of inflammation in the body.
details: Measured by the Westergren method, an elevated ESR suggests inflammation caused by infection, autoimmune disorders, or malignancy. Results vary by age and sex; a markedly high ESR (>100 mm/hr) may indicate severe disease.

name: Estradiol
description: Estradiol (E2) is the predominant form of estrogen produced by ovarian follicles in females and in smaller amounts by the adrenal glands and testes; it regulates reproductive health, bone density, and cardiovascular function.
details: Measured via immunoassay or mass spectrometry, estradiol levels fluctuate during the menstrual cycle: follicular phase lower, midcycle peak highest, then moderate luteal phase; levels are low in postmenopausal women and children. Abnormal levels may indicate reproductive disorders, endocrine tumors, or menopausal status.

name: Fasting Blood Sugar
description: Fasting Blood Sugar (Fasting Plasma Glucose) measures the concentration of glucose in the blood after at least 8 hours without caloric intake, reflecting baseline glucose metabolism.
details: According to ADA guidelines, a normal fasting blood sugar is between 70 and 99 mg/dL. Levels from 100 to 125 mg/dL indicate impaired fasting glucose (prediabetes), and a reading of 126 mg/dL or higher on two separate occasions is diagnostic for diabetes mellitus.

name: Food Tolerance Test
description: Measures immunoglobulin G (IgG) antibody responses to a variety of foods to assess potential food intolerances.
details: Food tolerance panels use ELISA assays to quantify IgG antibodies against individual food antigens. Higher IgG levels may indicate a delayed food sensitivity linked to gastrointestinal discomfort or systemic symptoms, though these tests lack universal clinical consensus and standard reference ranges.

name: Folate
description: Folate (vitamin B9) is a water-soluble vitamin essential for DNA synthesis, repair, and methylation, as well as red blood cell formation and fetal neural tube development.
details: Serum folate reflects recent dietary intake; levels below 5 ng/mL indicate deficiency, and values under 2 ng/mL are associated with megaloblastic anemia. Erythrocyte folate provides a longer-term status, with <140 ng/mL indicating deficiency. During pregnancy, higher folate levels (>13 ng/mL) are linked to reduced neural tube defect risk.

name: Fructosamine
description: Fructosamine reflects average blood glucose exposure over the preceding 2–3 weeks by measuring glycated serum proteins, predominantly albumin.
details: Used as a short-term glycemic control marker, fructosamine levels are particularly useful when HbA1c is unreliable (e.g., hemoglobin variants, altered red cell turnover). Normal non-diabetic range is ~190–285 µmol/L; levels >300 µmol/L suggest inadequate glycemic control over the past 2–3 weeks.

name: FSH (Follicle Stimulating Hormone)
description: FSH is a pituitary hormone that regulates the development, growth, pubertal maturation, and reproductive processes of the body by stimulating the ovaries in females and Sertoli cells in males.
details: Measured via immunoassay, FSH levels vary by age, sex, and menstrual cycle phase. Elevated levels may indicate ovarian failure or menopause in women and testicular failure in men; low levels may suggest pituitary/hypothalamic dysfunction.

name: Free PSA
description: Free PSA measures the percentage of prostate-specific antigen in the blood that is unbound to proteins, aiding in the differentiation between benign prostatic hyperplasia and prostate cancer.
details: Calculated as (free PSA / total PSA) × 100. A higher percentage of free PSA (>25%) suggests a lower risk of prostate cancer, whereas a lower percentage (<10%) is associated with a higher probability of malignancy. Intermediate values (10–25%) fall into a diagnostic gray zone where further investigation may be needed.

name: Free T3
description: Free triiodothyronine (Free T3) is the active form of thyroid hormone, regulating metabolic rate, growth, and development.
details: Measured via immunoassay or mass spectrometry, Free T3 represents the unbound fraction available to tissues. Elevated levels suggest hyperthyroidism and low levels indicate hypothyroidism or impaired conversion from T4.

name: Free T4
description: Free thyroxine (Free T4) is the unbound fraction of thyroxine hormone, responsible for regulating metabolism, growth, and development.
details: Measured via immunoassay or equilibrium dialysis, Free T4 reflects thyroid gland function. Elevated levels suggest hyperthyroidism; low levels indicate hypothyroidism or impaired thyroid hormone production.

name: Free Testosterone
description: Free testosterone is the fraction of circulating testosterone unbound to serum proteins, representing the biologically active form of the hormone.
details: Measured via immunoassay or mass spectrometry, free testosterone indicates the biologically available hormone. Adult males typically range from 50 to 210 pg/mL; low levels suggest hypogonadism, and high levels may indicate androgen excess or exogenous therapy.

name: Gamma Glutamyl Transferase
description: Gamma-glutamyl transferase (GGT) is an enzyme found predominantly in the liver that plays a key role in amino acid transport and glutathione metabolism.
details: Measured via enzymatic assays, elevated GGT levels indicate liver or bile duct injury, chronic alcohol use, or medication effects; low levels are rarely clinically significant.

name: Gene Test
description: Clinical genetic testing involves laboratory analysis of DNA, RNA, or chromosomes to aid in the diagnosis, management, and prevention of genetic conditions.
details: Genetic tests can confirm or rule out a suspected genetic condition, assess disease risk, guide therapy through pharmacogenomics, and perform identity or forensic analyses. Common techniques include molecular tests for gene mutations, chromosomal analysis, and genome-wide screening.

name: Gut Microbiome Test
description: A comprehensive analysis of the gut microbial community using stool DNA sequencing to assess microbial composition, diversity, and functional markers.
details: Gut microbiome tests use 16S rRNA gene sequencing or whole-genome shotgun metagenomics to identify bacterial, fungal, viral, and archaeal species. Reports typically include alpha diversity (e.g., Shannon index), relative abundance of key taxa, functional pathway predictions, and potential dysbiosis indicators. Variations exist between providers in methods, reference databases, and report metrics. For clinical decision-making, refer to consensus guidelines on microbiome testing.

name: HbA1C
description: Hemoglobin A1C measures the percentage of glycated hemoglobin, reflecting average blood glucose levels over the past 2–3 months.
details: Measured via high-performance liquid chromatography (HPLC) or immunoassay, HbA1C indicates long-term glycemic control. According to ADA criteria: <5.7% is normal; 5.7–6.4% indicates prediabetes; ≥6.5% diagnoses diabetes. For most adults with diabetes, the treatment target is <7%, individualized by age and comorbid conditions.

name: HDL Cholesterol
description: High-density lipoprotein (HDL) cholesterol helps remove excess cholesterol from the bloodstream and is protective against atherosclerosis.
details: Measured via enzymatic assays, HDL-C is reported in mg/dL. Levels below 40 mg/dL for men and below 50 mg/dL for women are associated with higher cardiovascular risk; levels above 60 mg/dL are considered protective. In children and adolescents, an HDL-C ≥45 mg/dL is desirable to support long-term heart health.

name: Hematocrit(pcv)
description: The percentage of blood volume occupied by red blood cells, also known as packed cell volume (PCV).
details: Determined by centrifugation of blood samples or calculated via automated analyzers as part of a complete blood count. High values may indicate dehydration or polycythemia; low values suggest anemia or blood loss.

name: Hemoglobin
description: Hemoglobin is the oxygen-carrying protein in red blood cells, essential for transporting oxygen throughout the body.
details: Measured via automated complete blood count (CBC) analyzers, hemoglobin levels indicate red blood cell mass. Low levels suggest anemia due to iron deficiency, blood loss, or chronic disease; high levels may indicate dehydration, polycythemia, or lung disease.

name: Hepatitis B surface antigen (HBsAg)
description: Detects the hepatitis B virus surface antigen in serum or plasma; a marker of acute or chronic HBV infection.
details: Measured by enzyme immunoassay or chemiluminescence: a ratio <1.0 is considered negative (nonreactive), 1.0–5.0 is indeterminate (equivocal) and should be repeated, and >5.0 is positive (reactive), indicating current HBV infection :contentReference[oaicite:0]{index=0}.

name: Herpes simplex virus 1 (HSV)-IgG
description: HSV-1 IgG antibody test detects immunoglobulin G antibodies specific to herpes simplex virus type 1, indicating past or latent infection.
details: Measured by enzyme immunoassay; results are reported as index ratios: <0.9 negative, 0.9–1.1 equivocal, >1.1 positive. A positive result indicates prior exposure to HSV-1; equivocal results may warrant repeat testing or confirmatory assays.

name: Herpes simplex virus 2 (HSV)-IgM
description: HSV-2 IgM antibody test detects immunoglobulin M antibodies specific to herpes simplex virus type 2, indicating recent or acute infection.
details: Measured by enzyme immunoassay; results are reported as index ratios: <0.9 negative, 0.9–1.1 equivocal, >1.1 positive. A positive IgM suggests recent HSV-2 infection; equivocal results may require retesting or confirmatory assays.

name: HIV ELISA
description: HIV ELISA (Enzyme-Linked Immunosorbent Assay) detects antibodies to HIV-1 and/or HIV-2, used for initial screening of HIV infection.
details: Measured by enzyme immunoassay; results are reported as index ratios: <0.9 negative (non-reactive), 0.9–1.1 equivocal, >1.1 positive (reactive). Positive or repeatedly reactive screens require confirmatory testing (e.g., Western blot or nucleic acid amplification).

name: Homocysteine
description: Homocysteine is a sulfur-containing amino acid in the blood; elevated levels are associated with cardiovascular disease, cognitive decline, and B-vitamin deficiencies.
details: Measured via blood assay, total homocysteine levels <15 µmol/L are considered normal. Levels of 15–30 µmol/L indicate moderate hyperhomocysteinemia; 30–100 µmol/L indicate intermediate; >100 µmol/L indicate severe elevation. Elevated homocysteine may result from genetic enzyme defects, vitamin B6/B12/folate deficiencies, renal impairment, or lifestyle factors and is a modifiable cardiovascular risk factor.

name: Immature granulocyte percentage(ig%)
description: The percentage of white blood cells that are immature granulocytes (promyelocytes, myelocytes, metamyelocytes), reflecting bone marrow activity and immune response.
details: Measured via automated hematology analyzers as part of a CBC with differential. In healthy adults, IG% is typically <1%; levels >2% indicate significant bone marrow stimulation seen in infections, inflammation, or hematologic disorders.

name: Immature granulocytes(ig)
description: Absolute count of immature granulocytes (promyelocytes, myelocytes, metamyelocytes) in peripheral blood, indicating early bone marrow precursor release during infection or inflammation.
details: Measured via automated hematology analyzers as part of a CBC. An absolute IG count <0.1 ×10^3/µL (<100 cells/µL) is considered normal; counts above 0.3 ×10^3/µL suggest significant marrow stimulation in severe infections or hematologic disorders.

name: Insulin
description: Insulin is a peptide hormone produced by pancreatic beta cells that regulates blood glucose by facilitating cellular uptake and storage of glucose.
details: Measured via immunoassay in fasting serum samples, insulin levels reflect pancreatic beta-cell function and insulin sensitivity. Fasting insulin levels of 2–20 µIU/mL are considered normal; values above 25 µIU/mL suggest hyperinsulinemia and potential insulin resistance. Levels below 1 µIU/mL may indicate beta-cell failure as seen in type 1 diabetes.

name: LDL/HDL Ratio
description: The ratio of low-density lipoprotein (LDL) cholesterol to high-density lipoprotein (HDL) cholesterol, used as a marker of cardiovascular risk; higher ratios indicate greater risk.
details: Calculated by dividing LDL cholesterol by HDL cholesterol. A lower ratio indicates a healthier lipid profile: ratios ≤3.0 are considered optimal for men (≤2.5 for women), 3.1–4.9 are borderline or moderate risk, and ≥5.0 indicate high cardiovascular risk. Values are interpreted in context of age, sex, and other risk factors.

name: LDL Cholesterol
description: Low-density lipoprotein cholesterol (LDL-C), often called 'bad' cholesterol, transports cholesterol to tissues and can deposit in arterial walls, increasing cardiovascular risk.
details: According to NCEP ATP III guidelines: <100 mg/dL is optimal; 100–129 mg/dL near optimal/above optimal; 130–159 mg/dL borderline high; 160–189 mg/dL high; ≥190 mg/dL very high. Elevated LDL-C is a major modifiable risk factor for atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease.

name: Lactate Dehydrogenase (LDH)
description: Lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) is an enzyme found in nearly all body tissues, involved in the conversion of lactate to pyruvate during energy production, and serves as a general marker of tissue damage.
details: Measured via enzymatic colorimetric assays in serum or plasma. Normal adult levels range from 140 to 280 U/L; elevations may indicate tissue damage from hemolysis, liver disease, myocardial infarction, muscle injury, or malignancies. Neonates and children have higher normal ranges, which decline to adult levels as they age.

name: Lead
description: Blood lead level measures the concentration of lead in blood, used to assess lead exposure and risk of toxicity.
details: Measured via atomic absorption spectroscopy or inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry (ICP-MS). The CDC identifies <5 µg/dL as the reference level for children; adults are at increased risk of toxicity above 10 µg/dL. Elevated lead levels can cause neurologic, hematologic, and renal effects, and require prompt investigation and mitigation.

name: Lipoprotein-A
description: Lipoprotein(a) [Lp(a)] is an LDL-like particle with apolipoprotein(a), contributing to atherogenesis and thrombosis.
details: Measured by immunoassay, Lp(a) levels are largely genetically determined and remain stable throughout life. Levels <30 mg/dL are considered normal; 30–50 mg/dL confer intermediate or borderline cardiovascular risk; >50 mg/dL are associated with high risk of atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease. Measurement may also be reported in nmol/L (with >125 nmol/L considered very high) depending on assay methodology.

name: Lp-PLA2
description: Lipoprotein-associated phospholipase A2 (Lp-PLA2) is an enzyme bound mainly to LDL that participates in vascular inflammation and atherosclerotic plaque formation.
details: Measured via immunoassay (e.g. PLAC test), Lp-PLA2 levels <200 ng/mL are considered normal. Levels between 200–300 ng/mL are borderline and associated with moderate increased cardiovascular risk; values >300 ng/mL confer high risk of coronary heart disease and stroke :contentReference[oaicite:0]{index=0}.

name: Lymphocyte percentage
description: The proportion of lymphocytes among total white blood cells, indicating immune system status.
details: Measured via automated hematology analyzers as part of a CBC with differential. In healthy adults, lymphocytes typically account for 20–40% of white blood cells; values <10% (lymphopenia) or >50% (lymphocytosis) may indicate underlying immune or hematologic conditions.

name: Lymphocytes - absolute count
description: The absolute count of lymphocytes, a type of white blood cell essential for adaptive immune responses.
details: Measured via automated hematology analyzers as part of a CBC with differential. Normal adult absolute lymphocyte counts range from 1,200 to 4,950 cells/µL, reflecting healthy immune function. Deviations may indicate infection, immune disorders, or hematologic diseases.

name: Magnesium
description: Serum magnesium measures the concentration of magnesium in the blood, crucial for neuromuscular, cardiac, and metabolic functions.
details: Measured via colorimetric or atomic absorption methods. Normal adult serum magnesium is 1.7–2.2 mg/dL; levels below 1.7 mg/dL indicate hypomagnesemia (symptoms: muscle cramps, arrhythmias) and above ~2.5 mg/dL may suggest hypermagnesemia, especially in renal impairment. Critically low (<1.2 mg/dL) and high (>3.0 mg/dL) levels can lead to neuromuscular and cardiac complications.

name: Manganese
description: Serum manganese measures the concentration of manganese, an essential trace element involved in enzyme activation, antioxidant defenses, and bone metabolism.
details: Measured via atomic absorption spectrometry or ICP-MS, normal adult serum manganese levels range from 4 to 15 µg/L. Levels below 3 µg/L may indicate deficiency affecting growth and metabolic functions; levels above 20 µg/L can suggest overexposure, leading to neurologic symptoms resembling Parkinsonism.

name: Mean corpuscular hemoglobin(mch)
description: Mean corpuscular hemoglobin measures the average amount of hemoglobin per red blood cell, reflecting oxygen-carrying capacity.
details: Measured as part of a CBC, MCH values indicate the average hemoglobin content in individual red blood cells. Normal adult levels are 27–31 pg/cell; levels <27 pg suggest microcytic anemia, while levels >31 pg indicate macrocytic conditions. Interpretation should consider MCV and MCHC for comprehensive red cell indices assessment.

name: Mean corp.hemo.conc (MCHC)
description: Mean corpuscular hemoglobin concentration (MCHC) measures the average concentration of hemoglobin in a given volume of packed red blood cells, reflecting cell chromicity.
details: Calculated as (hemoglobin [g/dL] ÷ hematocrit [%]) × 100. Low MCHC (hypochromia) suggests iron deficiency anemia or thalassemia; high MCHC (hyperchromia) is seen in hereditary spherocytosis or autoimmune hemolysis. Interpret alongside MCV and MCH for comprehensive red cell indices assessment.

name: Mean corpuscular volume(mcv)
description: Mean corpuscular volume measures the average volume of individual red blood cells, aiding in the classification of anemias.
details: Performed as part of a CBC, MCV reflects average red cell size. Normal adult MCV is 80–100 fL; macrocytosis (high MCV) is seen in vitamin B12/folate deficiency, liver disease, and alcohol use; microcytosis (low MCV) occurs in iron deficiency and thalassemia. Pediatric and neonatal ranges differ by age.

name: Mean platelet volume(mpv)
description: Mean platelet volume measures the average size of platelets in the blood, reflecting platelet production and activation.
details: Measured via automated hematology analyzers as part of a CBC. Normal adult MPV ranges from approximately 7.5 to 11.5 fL; values below this may indicate decreased platelet production (e.g., bone marrow disorders), while elevated MPV suggests increased platelet turnover or activation seen in inflammatory conditions and cardiovascular risk.

name: Mercury
description: Blood mercury level measures concentration of total mercury in whole blood, reflecting recent exposure to organic and inorganic forms.
details: Measured via inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry (ICP-MS) or cold vapor atomic absorption spectrometry (CVAAS). Normal blood mercury in the general population is <5 µg/L; levels between 5–10 µg/L may reflect elevated dietary or environmental exposures; levels >10 µg/L warrant clinical assessment, and levels >20 µg/L indicate significant exposure with risk of toxicity.

name: Monocytes
description: Monocytes are a type of white blood cell involved in phagocytosis and immune regulation; measured as a percentage of total leukocytes.
details: Measured via automated hematology analyzers as part of a CBC with differential. Normal adults have 2–8% monocytes; elevated levels (>10%) may indicate chronic inflammation or infection, while low levels (<2%) can be seen in bone marrow suppression.

name: Monocytes - absolute count
description: The absolute count of monocytes, a type of white blood cell involved in phagocytosis and immune regulation.
details: Measured via automated hematology analyzers as part of a CBC with differential. Normal adult absolute monocyte counts range from 200 to 950 cells/µL; elevated counts may indicate chronic inflammation, infection, or hematologic disorders.

name: Molybdenum
description: Serum molybdenum measures the concentration of molybdenum, a trace element essential for enzyme function, including xanthine oxidase and sulfite oxidase.
details: Measured via ICP-MS or atomic absorption. Normal serum molybdenum in healthy adults typically ranges from 0.3 to 3.0 µg/L (ng/mL) ([ods.od.nih.gov](https://ods.od.nih.gov/factsheets/Molybdenum-HealthProfessional/?utm_source=chatgpt.com), [healthmatters.io](https://healthmatters.io/understand-blood-test-results/molybdenum-8?utm_source=chatgpt.com)). Levels >10 µg/L may indicate excessive exposure, such as prosthetic device wear. Severe deficiency is rare and not routinely assessed.

name: Neutrophils
description: The proportion of neutrophils among total white blood cells, reflecting innate immune activity.
details: Measured via automated hematology analyzers as part of a CBC with differential. Neutrophils typically comprise 50–75% of circulating leukocytes in healthy adults; levels <45% suggest neutropenia and increased infection risk, while >80% (neutrophilia) suggest acute infection or inflammation :contentReference[oaicite:0]{index=0}.

name: Neutrophils – absolute count
description: The absolute number of neutrophils, a key component of innate immunity, per microliter of blood.
details: Calculated as (total WBC count × neutrophil %) from a CBC. An ANC ≥1500 cells/µL is considered normal in adults; 1000–1500 is mild neutropenia; <500 indicates severe neutropenia with high infection risk. Neutrophilia (>8000) suggests acute infection, inflammation, or stress responses :contentReference[oaicite:0]{index=0}.

name: Nickel
description: Blood nickel level measures concentration of nickel in whole blood or serum, used to assess recent exposure to nickel compounds.
details: Measured via ICP-MS or atomic absorption; blood should be collected with plastic-lined needles to avoid contamination. Normal levels are ≤10 µg/L; levels >10 µg/L suggest exposure and warrant investigation; levels >50 µg/L indicate significant toxicity risk.

name: Nitrite
description: Detects nitrites in urine, produced by bacterial reduction of nitrates, serving as a marker of bacterial urinary tract infection.
details: Performed via dipstick; a negative nitrite test (<0.05 mg/dL) is normal. A positive result is highly specific for bacteriuria by gram-negative, nitrate-reducing organisms (e.g., E. coli), though sensitivity is limited by urine dwell time and dietary nitrate. Positive tests warrant further microbiologic culture.

name: Non - HDL Cholesterol
description: Non-HDL cholesterol encompasses all atherogenic lipid particles (total cholesterol minus HDL-C), serving as a comprehensive measure of cardiovascular risk.
details: Calculated as total cholesterol minus HDL cholesterol. According to AHA guidelines, a non-HDL-C <130 mg/dL is optimal; 130–159 mg/dL is borderline high; 160–189 mg/dL is high; and ≥190 mg/dL is very high, reflecting increased risk of atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease and guiding lipid-lowering therapy targets.

name: Nucleated red blood cells
description: Absolute count of circulating nucleated red blood cells (erythroblasts), immature precursors normally confined to bone marrow.
details: Measured via automated analyzers or manual differential; normal adult peripheral blood contains no nucleated RBCs. Any count >0 cells/µL is abnormal, indicating marrow stress or extramedullary erythropoiesis. In term neonates, normal counts correspond to approximately 3–10 NRBCs per 100 WBCs (≈390–3,800 cells/µL based on typical WBC counts of 13,000–38,000/µL), and in preterm infants up to 25 NRBCs per 100 WBCs (≈3,250–9,500 cells/µL).

name: Nucleated red blood cells %
description: Percentage of nucleated red blood cells relative to total white blood cells, indicating abnormal erythropoiesis when present.
details: Reported as NRBCs per 100 WBCs; normal adult percentage is 0%. In term neonates, normal is 3–10% for the first few days of life, and in preterm infants up to 25%. Values above 0% in adults are abnormal and warrant investigation.

name: Omega-3 Index
description: Measures the percentage of EPA and DHA in red blood cell membranes as a long-term biomarker of omega-3 status and cardiovascular health.
details: The Omega-3 Index reflects long-term intake of EPA and DHA, with levels ≥8% associated with reduced risk of cardiovascular disease, sudden cardiac death, cognitive decline, and systemic inflammation; 4–8% is considered intermediate; <4% indicates deficient status and elevated risk. Testing is performed via RBC membrane analysis or dried blood spot assays.

name: Omega-6 & Omega-3 Fatty acids
description: Dietary or blood biomarkers assessing the balance between omega-6 and omega-3 polyunsaturated fatty acids, crucial for modulating inflammation and cardiovascular health.
details: The omega-6 to omega-3 ratio reflects dietary intake or red blood cell membrane composition. Ancestral diets had ratios near 1:1; modern Western diets often exceed 15:1. Optimal health outcomes are associated with ratios between 1:1 and 4:1, reducing chronic inflammation and cardiovascular risk; ratios above 10:1 are linked to increased risk of inflammatory diseases. Measurement can be via dietary assessment or blood fatty acid profiling.

name: pH
description: The hydrogen ion concentration of blood, reflecting systemic acid–base status.
details: Measured via arterial blood gas (ABG) or venous blood gas (VBG) analysis. Normal arterial pH is 7.35–7.45, and normal venous pH is 7.31–7.41; pH below 7.35 indicates acidosis, above 7.45 indicates alkalosis. Values outside the warning thresholds (7.30–7.50) warrant clinical review, and levels below 7.20 or above 7.60 are critical and require immediate intervention.

name: Phosphorous
description: Serum phosphorus measures the concentration of inorganic phosphate in the blood, essential for bone mineralization, energy metabolism, and acid–base balance.
details: Measured via colorimetric or enzymatic assays, normal adult serum phosphorus ranges from 2.5 to 4.5 mg/dL; levels below 2.5 mg/dL indicate hypophosphatemia (symptoms: muscle weakness, bone pain, hemolysis), and levels above 4.5 mg/dL indicate hyperphosphatemia (often due to renal failure, hypoparathyroidism) ([webmd.com](https://www.webmd.com/a-to-z-guides/phosphate-blood-test?utm_source=chatgpt.com), [ods.od.nih.gov](https://ods.od.nih.gov/factsheets/Phosphorus-HealthProfessional/?utm_source=chatgpt.com)).

name: Platelet count
description: The number of platelets (thrombocytes) in a given volume of blood, essential for normal blood clotting and hemostasis.
details: Measured via automated hematology analyzers as part of a complete blood count. Normal adult platelet counts range from 150,000 to 450,000 cells/µL; counts below 150,000 indicate thrombocytopenia (with mild: 100,000–150,000; moderate: 50,000–100,000; severe: <50,000) and counts above 450,000 indicate thrombocytosis. Critical values (<20,000 or >1,000,000 cells/µL) require immediate clinical attention.

name: Platelet distribution width(pdw)
description: Platelet distribution width quantifies the variability in platelet size, reflecting heterogeneity in platelet morphology and activation status.
details: Measured as part of a CBC using automated hematology analyzers, PDW values between 9% and 17% are considered normal, indicating uniform platelet size distribution. Elevated PDW (>17%) suggests increased platelet activation or anisocytosis and is associated with conditions such as bone marrow disorders, inflammatory states, and cardiovascular disease ([drlogy.com](https://www.drlogy.com/test/pdw-blood?utm_source=chatgpt.com), [redcliffelabs.com](https://redcliffelabs.com/myhealth/lab-test/platelet-distribution-width-pdw-test-symptoms-causes-and-management/?utm_source=chatgpt.com)).

name: Platelet to large cell ratio(plcr)
description: Platelet – large cell ratio (P‑LCR) measures the percentage of circulating platelets larger than 12 fL, reflecting platelet production and activation.
details: Calculated as (number of platelets >12 fL ÷ total platelet count) ×100. Normal adult P‑LCR ranges from 15% to 35%; values above 35% may indicate increased platelet turnover or activation seen in inflammatory conditions and cardiovascular risk; markedly elevated P‑LCR (>50%) warrants further evaluation for thrombotic disorders. P‑LCR correlates with mean platelet volume and platelet distribution width.

name: Plateletcrit(pct)
description: Plateletcrit (PCT) is the volume percentage of blood occupied by platelets, reflecting total platelet mass.
details: PCT is calculated as (platelet count × mean platelet volume) ÷ 10,000. Normal adult ranges are 0.22–0.24%; values below ~0.20% indicate thrombocytopenia and values above ~0.36% suggest thrombocytosis or elevated platelet mass. PCT provides insight into platelet production and activation and is included as part of platelet indices.

name: Progesterone
description: Progesterone is a steroid hormone produced by the corpus luteum and placenta, essential for regulating the menstrual cycle, supporting early pregnancy, and modulating immune function.
details: Progesterone levels vary across the menstrual cycle and pregnancy: very low in the follicular phase, rise after ovulation, and peak during the luteal phase; substantially higher during each trimester of pregnancy. Abnormal values can indicate luteal phase defects, pregnancy complications, or endocrine disorders.

name: Protein – Total
description: Total serum protein measures the combined concentration of albumin and globulin in blood, reflecting nutritional status, liver and kidney function, and immune health.
details: Measured via biochemical assays as part of a comprehensive metabolic panel, total protein levels of 6.0–8.3 g/dL are considered normal in adults. Low levels (<6.0 g/dL) suggest malnutrition, liver or kidney disorders, while high levels (>8.3 g/dL) may indicate chronic inflammation, multiple myeloma, or dehydration. Laboratory methods include biuret reaction and refractometry.

name: Prostate Specific Antigen (PSA)
description: Prostate-specific antigen (PSA) is a glycoprotein produced by prostate epithelial cells; blood levels are used for screening and monitoring prostate cancer.
details: Measured via immunoassay in serum. PSA levels <4 ng/mL are generally considered normal; 4–10 ng/mL is borderline (25% risk of cancer) and often requires further evaluation; >10 ng/mL is high (50–65% risk of prostate cancer) ([webmd.com](https://www.webmd.com/prostate-cancer/psa?utm_source=chatgpt.com)). Age-specific thresholds per NICE NG12: <50 years <2.5 ng/mL; 50–59 years <3.5 ng/mL; 60–69 years <4.5 ng/mL; ≥70 years <6.5 ng/mL ([ouh.nhs.uk](https://www.ouh.nhs.uk/biochemistry/tests/tests-catalogue/psa.aspx?utm_source=chatgpt.com)). PSA can also rise in benign prostatic hyperplasia, prostatitis, or recent urinary instrumentation. Screening generally begins at age 55, or earlier in high-risk groups ([medicinenet.com](https://www.medicinenet.com/what_is_a_normal_psa_level_by_age/article.htm?utm_source=chatgpt.com)).

name: Red cell distribution width (RDW-CV)
description: RDW-CV (Coefficient of Variation) measures the variability in size of circulating red blood cells, expressed as a percentage of the mean corpuscular volume (MCV).
details: Calculated as (standard deviation of red blood cell volume ÷ MCV) × 100. A normal RDW-CV (11.5–14.5%) indicates uniform cell sizes; values >14.5% reflect anisocytosis seen in iron-deficiency, B₁₂/folate deficiencies, mixed anemias, and other hematologic disorders :contentReference[oaicite:0]{index=0}. Very high values (>20%) suggest severe variation often associated with acute hemolysis or marrow stress.

name: Red cell distribution width - sd (RDW-SD)
description: RDW-SD measures the width (in femtoliters) of the red blood cell size distribution histogram at the 20% height level, reflecting variation in cell volumes independent of mean corpuscular volume.
details: Calculated directly from the RBC volume histogram; normal adult RDW-SD is 39–46 fL. Elevated RDW-SD indicates anisocytosis seen in iron deficiency, B₁₂/folate deficiencies, mixed anemias, and other marrow disorders :contentReference[oaicite:0]{index=0}.

name: Rheumatoid Factor (RF factor)
description: An autoantibody directed against the Fc portion of IgG, commonly measured to help diagnose rheumatoid arthritis and other autoimmune diseases.
details: Measured by immunoassay or latex agglutination, RF is present in approximately 70% of rheumatoid arthritis patients but can also occur in other autoimmune disorders and in 5–10% of healthy individuals. A level <20 IU/mL is considered negative; 20–60 IU/mL is a weak positive; >60 IU/mL is strongly positive and correlates with more severe disease. RF testing is often accompanied by anti-CCP for greater specificity.

name: RMR Testing
description: Resting metabolic rate (RMR) measures the energy expended by the body at rest to maintain basic physiological functions.
details: Measured via indirect calorimetry or estimated using predictive equations (Harris–Benedict, Mifflin–St Jeor). Typical RMR for adult females is about 1,200–1,500 kcal/day and for adult males about 1,500–1,800 kcal/day; RMR can range from <1,200 to over 3,000 kcal/day depending on age, sex, lean body mass, and genetics, and typically declines ~2% per decade after early adulthood.

name: Serum Albumin
description: Serum albumin is the most abundant plasma protein, synthesized in the liver, vital for maintaining oncotic pressure and transporting hormones, drugs, and ions.
details: Measured via bromocresol green or purple assays in serum. Normal adult levels are 3.5–5.0 g/dL; hypoalbuminemia (<3.5 g/dL) can indicate liver disease, nephrotic syndrome, malnutrition, or inflammation; hyperalbuminemia (>5.0 g/dL) is rare and usually due to dehydration. Laboratory methods and reference ranges may vary slightly by assay and population.

name: Serum Albumin / Globulin Ratio
description: The ratio of serum albumin to globulin, reflecting the balance of major plasma proteins and aiding in assessment of liver function, nutritional status, and immune disorders.
details: Calculated as albumin divided by (total protein minus albumin). A normal A/G ratio is 1.0–2.2. Low ratios (<1.0) may indicate hypoalbuminemia due to liver disease or nephrotic syndrome, or elevated globulins from chronic inflammation or multiple myeloma. High ratios (>2.2) can reflect low globulin levels seen in immunodeficiency or protein-losing conditions.

name: Serum Creatinine
description: Serum creatinine is a breakdown product of creatine phosphate in muscle, used to assess kidney filtration function.
details: Measured via enzymatic or Jaffe methods, normal adult male creatinine is 0.74–1.35 mg/dL and adult female is 0.59–1.04 mg/dL; values above these ranges indicate reduced glomerular filtration rate and possible renal impairment; values below may reflect low muscle mass or severe malnutrition. Infant levels start around 0.2 mg/dL and vary with age.

name: Serum Ferritin
description: Ferritin is the primary intracellular iron storage protein; serum levels reflect total body iron stores.
details: Measured by immunoassay, serum ferritin correlates with iron stores. In adults assigned male at birth, normal is 12–300 ng/mL; for adults assigned female, 10–150 ng/mL ([emedicine.medscape.com](https://emedicine.medscape.com/article/2085454-overview?utm_source=chatgpt.com), [medicinenet.com](https://www.medicinenet.com/ferritin_blood_test/article.htm?utm_source=chatgpt.com)). Newborns may have elevated levels (25–200 ng/mL), infants 1–30 days (200–600 ng/mL), 2–5 months (50–200 ng/mL), and children 6 months–15 years (7–142 ng/mL) ([emedicine.medscape.com](https://emedicine.medscape.com/article/2085454-overview?utm_source=chatgpt.com), [webmd.com](https://www.webmd.com/a-to-z-guides/ferritin-blood-test?utm_source=chatgpt.com)). Low ferritin (<12 ng/mL) indicates depleted iron stores and risk of iron-deficiency anemia; elevated ferritin may reflect iron overload (hemochromatosis), inflammation, liver disease, or malignancy and warrants clinical correlation.

name: Serum Globulin
description: Serum globulins are a group of plasma proteins including immunoglobulins, transport proteins, and clotting factors, calculated as total protein minus albumin.
details: Measured by subtracting serum albumin from total serum protein. Low globulin levels (<2.0 g/dL) may indicate immunodeficiency, malnutrition, or liver disease; elevated levels (>3.5 g/dL) occur in chronic inflammation, infections, and plasma cell disorders like multiple myeloma.

name: Serum Iron
description: Serum iron measures the amount of circulating iron bound to transferrin, helping assess iron absorption, transport, and potential deficiency or overload.
details: Measured via colorimetric or atomic absorption assays on serum samples. Normal adult males typically range from 70 to 175 µg/dL, and adult females from 50 to 150 µg/dL; diurnal variation affects levels, with highest values in the morning and lowest in the afternoon([bloodtestsresults.com](https://www.bloodtestsresults.com/2024/12/iron-blood-test-normal-iron-levels-chart-by-age.html?utm_source=chatgpt.com), [emedicine.medscape.com](https://emedicine.medscape.com/article/2085704-overview?utm_source=chatgpt.com)).

name: Serum Lipase
description: Serum lipase is a pancreatic enzyme that catalyzes the hydrolysis of dietary fats; elevated levels indicate pancreatic inflammation or injury.
details: Measured via enzymatic assay. Normal adult serum lipase ranges from 0 to 160 U/L, though laboratories may report 10–140 U/L depending on methodology. Lipase levels begin to rise 4–8 hours after pancreatic injury, peak around 24 hours, and return to normal within 8–14 days. Elevated lipase is most often due to acute or chronic pancreatitis but can also occur in renal failure, gastrointestinal perforation, or cholecystitis.

name: Serum Amylase
description: Serum amylase is a digestive enzyme produced by the pancreas and salivary glands; elevated levels indicate pancreatic injury or salivary gland dysfunction.
details: Measured via enzymatic assay. Normal adult serum amylase ranges from 30 to 110 U/L; levels rise within 4–8 hours of pancreatic injury, peak at 24 hours, and return to normal in 3–7 days. Elevated amylase is most commonly due to acute or chronic pancreatitis but can also occur in salivary gland disorders, intestinal obstruction, or renal impairment.

name: Sex Hormone Binding Globulin (SHBG)
description: SHBG is a glycoprotein produced by the liver that binds and transports sex steroids (testosterone, estradiol, DHT) in the blood, regulating their bioavailability.
details: Measured via immunoassay, SHBG levels vary by age and sex. Lower SHBG increases free sex hormone fractions and is linked to insulin resistance and PCOS, while elevated SHBG can indicate liver disease or hyperthyroidism. Levels rise with age and during pregnancy.

name: SGOT (AST)
description: Serum glutamic-oxaloacetic transaminase (SGOT), also known as aspartate aminotransferase (AST), is an enzyme found in liver, heart, skeletal muscle, and other tissues; elevated blood levels indicate tissue injury.
details: Measured via enzymatic assay in serum, AST levels rise 4–6 hours after acute tissue injury, peak at 24–48 hours, and normalize within 7–10 days. Elevations occur in acute hepatitis, myocardial infarction, muscle injury, and hemolysis. Interpretation should consider ALT and clinical context.

name: SGPT (ALT)
description: Serum glutamate pyruvate transaminase (SGPT), also known as alanine aminotransferase (ALT), is a liver enzyme; elevated levels indicate hepatocellular injury.
details: Measured via enzymatic assay in serum. Normal adult ALT levels range from 7 to 56 U/L; levels rise within 4–6 hours of liver injury, peak at 24–48 hours, and normalize within 7–10 days. Elevations occur in acute and chronic hepatitis, fatty liver disease, and other hepatic or muscular disorders. Interpretation should consider AST and clinical context.

name: Selenium
description: Serum selenium measures the concentration of selenium, an essential micronutrient and cofactor for antioxidant enzymes and thyroid hormone metabolism.
details: Measured via ICP-MS or atomic absorption spectroscopy. Normal adult serum selenium ranges from 70 to 150 µg/L; levels >300 µg/L may indicate toxicity (selenosis) with symptoms like gastrointestinal upset and hair loss, and levels >1000 µg/L denote severe toxicity. Selenium deficiency (<70 µg/L) is linked to cardiomyopathy (Keshan disease) and impaired immune or thyroid function.

name: Silver
description: Blood silver level measures total silver concentration in whole blood, reflecting exposure to silver compounds and risk of argyria or toxicity.
details: Measured via ICP-MS or atomic absorption spectroscopy. Typical blood silver in non-exposed individuals is <2.3 µg/L; levels between 2.3 and 5 µg/L suggest mild exposure; 5–10 µg/L moderate exposure; >10 µg/L indicate significant exposure and increased risk of argyria or renal impairment. Silver has no known physiological role and accumulates in skin and organs with prolonged exposure, leading to irreversible discoloration and potential organ toxicity ([sciencedirect.com](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0305417914003052?utm_source=chatgpt.com), [healthmatters.io](https://healthmatters.io/understand-blood-test-results/silver-4?utm_source=chatgpt.com)).

name: Specific gravity
description: Measures the concentration of solutes in urine, reflecting hydration status and renal concentrating ability.
details: Measured via refractometry or dipstick analysis. Normal values range from 1.005 to 1.030; values below 1.005 suggest overhydration or dilute urine (e.g., diabetes insipidus), while values above 1.030 indicate concentrated urine from dehydration or presence of high solute load (e.g., glucose, protein). Values outside 1.001–1.035 warrant further clinical evaluation.

name: Strontium
description: Blood strontium level measures the concentration of strontium, a trace element that accumulates in bone and is mobilized in response to calcium levels, and reflects exposure to environmental or occupational sources.
details: Measured via inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry (ICP-MS) or atomic absorption spectroscopy. Normal whole blood strontium levels range from approximately 8.3 to 34.3 µg/L in human populations, with other studies reporting ranges up to 45 µg/L; elevated levels can indicate environmental or occupational exposure and may have implications for bone health and renal clearance.

name: TC/HDL Cholesterol Ratio
description: The ratio of total cholesterol to HDL cholesterol, used as a predictor of cardiovascular disease risk; higher ratios indicate greater risk.
details: Calculated by dividing total cholesterol by HDL cholesterol. An optimal ratio is considered below 3.5:1; ratios up to 5:1 are acceptable for general population; ratios between 5:1 and 6:1 confer increased risk, and ratios above 6:1 are associated with high cardiovascular risk. This measure provides complementary information to individual lipid values and reflects the balance of atherogenic and protective lipoproteins. Regular monitoring can guide lifestyle and pharmacologic interventions.

name: Testosterone
description: Testosterone is the primary male sex hormone produced by the testes and a key androgen in females produced by the ovaries and adrenal glands, regulating reproductive function, muscle mass, bone density, and mood.
details: Measured via immunoassay or mass spectrometry on fasting morning blood samples due to diurnal variation (peak levels in early morning). Normal adult male total testosterone ranges from 300 to 1,000 ng/dL; adult female levels are 15 to 70 ng/dL. Levels decline gradually with age in men (e.g., 400–1080 ng/dL in ages 20–39, 350–890 ng/dL in ages 40–59, 156–859 ng/dL in ≥60 years). Abnormal low levels in men (<300 ng/dL) indicate hypogonadism, while elevated levels (>1000 ng/dL) suggest exogenous androgen use; in women, high levels may indicate PCOS or adrenal disorders.

name: Thallium
description: Blood thallium level measures the concentration of thallium, a highly toxic heavy metal, reflecting recent exposure and risk of poisoning.
details: Measured via inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry (ICP-MS), normal whole blood thallium levels are ≤2.0 µg/L. Blood levels >100 µg/L are considered toxic, and levels >300 µg/L indicate severe ingestion and correlate with systemic toxicity (gastrointestinal, neurologic, alopecia). Thallium has a biological half-life of 2–4 days and requires confirmatory testing using a metal-free collection tube if contamination is suspected.

name: Thyroid Stimulating Hormone (TSH)
description: TSH is a pituitary glycoprotein hormone that regulates thyroid gland activity via feedback control of T3 and T4 secretion, serving as the most sensitive marker of thyroid function.
details: Measured by immunoassay, TSH levels below 0.4 mIU/L suggest hyperthyroidism, and levels above 4.0 mIU/L indicate hypothyroidism. Pregnancy-specific ranges are: first trimester 0.1–2.5 mIU/L, second trimester 0.2–3.0 mIU/L, and third trimester 0.3–3.0 mIU/L. Neonatal and pediatric reference intervals vary: infants up to 5 days 0.7–15.2 mIU/L, 6–90 days 0.72–11.0 mIU/L, children 1–6 years 0.7–5.97 mIU/L, 7–11 years 0.6–4.84 mIU/L, and adolescents 12–20 years 0.51–4.30 mIU/L.

name: Tin
description: Blood tin level measures the total concentration of tin in whole blood, reflecting exposure to environmental or occupational sources.
details: Measured via inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry (ICP-MS). Normal blood tin concentrations are reported between 2 and 9 µg/L; levels above 20 µg/L may indicate significant exposure and warrant investigation, while levels above 100 µg/L are associated with acute or chronic toxicity symptoms such as gastrointestinal irritation, neurological effects, and renal impairment.

name: Total Cholesterol
description: Total cholesterol measures the sum of all cholesterol types in the blood (LDL, HDL, VLDL) and is a key predictor of atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease.
details: Measured via enzymatic assays in serum or plasma, total cholesterol <200 mg/dL is considered desirable; 200–239 mg/dL is borderline high; ≥240 mg/dL is high, indicating increased risk of coronary heart disease and stroke. In children, levels <170 mg/dL are recommended. Management includes lifestyle modifications and pharmacotherapy as guided by overall risk profile.

name: Total IgE
description: Total immunoglobulin E measures the cumulative concentration of IgE antibodies in serum, reflecting atopic sensitization and allergic disease burden.
details: Measured via immunoassay, total IgE levels <100 kU/L are considered normal; 100–200 kU/L indicate mild elevation; 200–1000 kU/L reflect moderate to high atopy; >1000 kU/L suggests severe allergic disease or parasitic infection. Used alongside specific IgE testing to guide allergy diagnosis and management.

name: Total Iron Binding Capacity
description: Total iron-binding capacity (TIBC) measures the maximum amount of iron that can be bound by plasma proteins, primarily transferrin, reflecting iron transport capacity and status.
details: Measured via colorimetric or immunoassay methods, TIBC indicates transferrin availability. Elevated levels (>450 µg/dL) often reflect iron deficiency, while low levels (<240 µg/dL) can indicate iron overload (e.g., hemochromatosis) or chronic inflammatory states. Accurate interpretation requires concurrent serum iron and transferrin saturation measurements.

name: Total leucocytes count
description: Total white blood cell (leukocyte) count, indicating the immune cell concentration in peripheral blood.
details: Measured via automated hematology analyzers as part of a CBC. Normal adult WBC count ranges from 4,000 to 11,000 cells/µL.
