Leukopenia (<4,000) may indicate bone marrow suppression, severe infection, or autoimmune disease; leukocytosis (>11,000) can reflect infection, inflammation, stress, or hematologic malignancies. Critical values (<1,000 or >30,000 cells/µL) require immediate evaluation.

name: Total RBC
description: Total red blood cell (erythrocyte) count, reflecting the number of circulating RBCs essential for oxygen transport.
details: Measured via automated hematology analyzers as part of a CBC. Normal adult male RBC count is 4.7–6.1 million/µL, and adult female is 4.2–5.4 million/µL; values below 4.2 million/µL or above 5.5 million/µL warrant follow-up. Pediatric (children) ranges are approximately 4.0–5.5 million/µL. RBC counts vary with age, sex, altitude, and hydration status.

name: Total Thyroxine (T4)
description: Total thyroxine (T4) measures both bound and free thyroxine in serum, reflecting overall thyroid hormone production.
details: Measured via immunoassay or equilibrium dialysis; total T4 levels vary with age and binding protein levels. Elevated levels may indicate hyperthyroidism, thyroid hormone replacement overdose, or familial dysalbuminemic hyperthyroxinemia. Low levels suggest hypothyroidism or pituitary dysfunction. Interpretation requires correlation with TSH and free T4.

name: Total Triiodothyronine (T3)
description: Total T3 measures both bound and free triiodothyronine, the active thyroid hormone, reflecting overall thyroid function and metabolic rate.
details: Measured via immunoassay or RIA on fasting blood samples due to diurnal variation. Normal adult levels are approximately 80–200 ng/dL; levels below suggest hypothyroidism, and elevated levels indicate hyperthyroidism or thyroid hormone excess. Interpretation requires correlation with TSH and T4.

name: Triglycerides
description: Triglycerides are a type of fat in the blood, stored in adipose tissue and used for energy; elevated levels are linked to cardiovascular disease and pancreatitis.
details: Measured via serum lipid panel after an overnight fast, triglyceride levels <150 mg/dL are considered normal; 150–199 mg/dL borderline high; 200–499 mg/dL high; and ≥500 mg/dL very high, with levels >1000 mg/dL posing risk for pancreatitis. Management includes lifestyle modifications and pharmacotherapy when indicated.

name: Treponema pallidum antibody (TPAB)
description: TPAB detects antibodies (IgG and/or IgM) against Treponema pallidum, the causative agent of syphilis, used for screening and diagnosis.
details: Measured via enzyme immunoassay or chemiluminescence; results reported as index values: <0.9 negative, 0.9–1.1 equivocal, >1.1 positive. A positive screen requires confirmatory testing (e.g., TPHA, FTA-ABS). IgM positivity suggests recent infection, while IgG indicates past or current infection.

name: Treponema pallidum haemagglutination (TPHA)
description: TPHA is a confirmatory serologic assay detecting antibodies to Treponema pallidum through passive hemagglutination of sensitized erythrocytes.
details: Performed by mixing patient serum with tanned erythrocytes coated with Treponema pallidum antigen. Results are reported as the highest serum dilution (titer) exhibiting visible agglutination. A titer ≥1:80 is considered reactive for syphilis confirmation; <1:80 is nonreactive and rules out active infection. TPHA remains positive for life in treated or untreated individuals and is used with quantitative nontreponemal tests to monitor treatment response.

name: Uranium
description: Blood uranium level measures the concentration of uranium isotopes in whole blood, reflecting recent exposure to uranium compounds.
details: Measured via inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry (ICP-MS) in metal-free collection tubes. Typical background blood uranium levels in non-exposed populations are <2 µg/L. Levels between 2–5 µg/L suggest low-level environmental exposure; 5–20 µg/L indicate moderate exposure, often in occupational settings; >20 µg/L correlate with significant exposure and potential nephrotoxic risk. Chronic high-level exposure may lead to renal tubular damage and increased cancer risk.

name: Uric Acid
description: Serum uric acid is the end product of purine metabolism, with levels influenced by production, renal excretion, and diet.
details: Measured via enzymatic or colorimetric assays on fasting blood samples. Normal adult male levels are 3.4–7.0 mg/dL and adult female levels are 2.4–6.0 mg/dL; levels below 2.0 mg/dL are rare and suggest hypouricemia, while levels above 8.0 mg/dL indicate hyperuricemia with risk for gout and kidney stones. Critically elevated levels (>12 mg/dL) may lead to acute urate nephropathy and require urgent management. Management includes diet modification, hydration, and urate‐lowering therapies when indicated.

name: Uri. Albumin/Creatinine Ratio (UA/C)
description: Urinary albumin-to-creatinine ratio measures albumin excretion normalized to creatinine, indicating kidney damage and proteinuria severity.
details: Measured on a spot urine sample; a ratio <30 mg albumin/g creatinine is normal. Ratios 30–300 mg/g (microalbuminuria) indicate early kidney damage, and >300 mg/g (macroalbuminuria) reflect overt proteinuria. Used for screening and monitoring diabetic and hypertensive nephropathy.

name: Urinary bilirubin
description: Detects bilirubin in urine, indicating conjugated hyperbilirubinemia from liver dysfunction or biliary obstruction.
details: Tested via dipstick or chemical assay; normal urine contains no bilirubin. Trace amounts (0.1–0.4 mg/dL) suggest mild cholestasis; 0.5–1.0 mg/dL indicate moderate elevation; >1.0 mg/dL signifies significant biliary obstruction or hepatocellular disease. Positive urine bilirubin warrants confirmatory serum bilirubin and liver function testing.

name: Urinary glucose
description: Detects glucose in urine, indicating renal threshold exceedance due to hyperglycemia or renal glycosuria.
details: Measured via urine dipstick or chemical assay. Normal urine contains little to no glucose (≤15 mg/dL) ([ucsfhealth.org](https://www.ucsfhealth.org/medical-tests/glucose-urine-test?utm_source=chatgpt.com)). Trace glucose (15–50 mg/dL) may reflect transient hyperglycemia or renal glycosuria, while higher concentrations (>50 mg/dL) indicate significant glucosuria often seen in diabetes mellitus. Glycosuria occurs when blood glucose exceeds the renal threshold (~180 mg/dL) ([emedicine.medscape.com](https://emedicine.medscape.com/article/2074001-overview?utm_source=chatgpt.com)). Interpretation requires correlation with blood glucose measurements and clinical context.

name: Urinary ketone
description: Detects ketone bodies (acetoacetate, beta-hydroxybutyrate, acetone) in urine, indicating fat metabolism and potential diabetic ketoacidosis or fasting state.
details: Measured via urine dipstick or quantitative assay. Negative urine ketones (0 mg/dL) are normal. Trace ketones (~5 mg/dL) can appear during prolonged fasting or low-carbohydrate diets; small levels (15 mg/dL) may suggest mild ketosis; moderate (40 mg/dL) and large (≥80 mg/dL) levels are seen in diabetic ketoacidosis or starvation. Positive results warrant blood ketone and glucose correlation

name: Urinary leucocytes
description: Counts white blood cells in urine, indicating pyuria and possible urinary tract infection or inflammation.
details: Measured via microscopy as WBC per high-power field (HPF). Normal urine contains up to 5 WBC/HPF; 6–10 WBC/HPF suggests mild pyuria; >10 WBC/HPF indicates significant pyuria often due to urinary tract infection, inflammation, or contamination.

name: Urinary Microalbumin
description: Quantitative measurement of albumin in urine, indicative of early kidney damage and microvascular disease.
details: Measured via immunoassay on a spot or timed urine collection. Urinary albumin <30 mg/L is normal; 30–300 mg/L (microalbuminuria) indicates early glomerular damage, commonly in diabetes or hypertension; >300 mg/L (macroalbuminuria) reflects overt proteinuria. Screening and monitoring utilize this marker for nephropathy risk assessment.

name: Urine blood
description: Detection of red blood cells in urine, indicating hematuria from urinary tract sources.
details: Measured via microscopy as RBCs per high-power field (HPF) or via urine dipstick semiquantitative (trace, small, moderate, large). Normal urine contains up to 2 RBC/HPF. Mild hematuria is 3–5 RBC/HPF; significant hematuria is >5 RBC/HPF and warrants evaluation for urinary tract infection, stones, or renal pathology.

name: Urinary protein
description: Protein in urine (proteinuria) reflects abnormal glomerular or tubular permeability and can indicate kidney damage or systemic disease.
details: Measured by dipstick or quantitative assays. A random (spot) urine protein ≤30 mg/dL (<150 mg/day) is normal. Levels 30–300 mg/dL indicate moderate proteinuria (often early kidney damage), and >300 mg/dL (nephrotic-range proteinuria) suggests significant glomerular disease. A 24-hour collection with total protein <150 mg/day is normal; ≥3.5 g/day confirms nephrotic syndrome.

name: Urobilinogen
description: Urobilinogen is a colorless byproduct of bilirubin reduction by intestinal bacteria; small amounts are reabsorbed and excreted in urine.
details: Measured via dipstick or laboratory assay. Normal urine urobilinogen is 0.2–1.0 mg/dL; levels below 0.2 mg/dL may suggest biliary obstruction, and levels above 1.0 mg/dL indicate increased bilirubin turnover from hemolysis or liver dysfunction. Very high levels (>2.0 mg/dL) warrant prompt evaluation for hepatic disease or hemolytic states.

name: Vanadium
description: Serum vanadium level measures the concentration of vanadium, a trace metal with potential roles in enzyme function and known toxicity at elevated exposures.
details: Measured via inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry (ICP-MS). Typical background serum vanadium levels range from 0.05 to 0.5 µg/L; levels above 1.0 µg/L suggest elevated environmental or occupational exposure, and levels >10 µg/L are associated with systemic toxicity including renal and neurological effects. Vanadium accumulates in bone and kidney tissue with chronic exposure.

name: VDRL (Venereal disease research laboratory)
description: A nontreponemal serologic test detecting reagin antibodies against cardiolipin-lecithin-cholesterol antigen to screen for syphilis.
details: Performed by flocculation or rapid plasma reagin (RPR) techniques. A nonreactive result indicates absence of reagin antibodies; a reactive result requires confirmatory treponemal testing (e.g., TPHA, FTA-ABS). Titers may be reported (e.g., 1:2, 1:8) and used to monitor treatment response, with a fourfold decline indicating effective therapy.

name: VLDL Cholesterol
description: Very low-density lipoprotein cholesterol, estimated from triglycerides, carries triglycerides in the blood and contributes to atherosclerosis when elevated.
details: Estimated as one-fifth of triglyceride concentration; normal VLDL levels are 2–30 mg/dL, 30–40 mg/dL is borderline high, and >40 mg/dL indicates increased cardiovascular risk. Management focuses on reducing triglycerides through diet, exercise, and medications when needed.

name: Vitamin A
description: Serum retinol (vitamin A) measures circulating vitamin A, essential for vision, immune function, and epithelial integrity.
details: Measured via HPLC or immunoassay. Serum retinol 20–60 µg/dL is normal; 10–20 µg/dL indicates marginal status; <10 µg/dL denotes deficiency with risk of night blindness and immune dysfunction. Levels >100 µg/dL are above recommended range and may indicate excess intake; >200 µg/dL risk hypervitaminosis A (hepatotoxicity, intracranial hypertension).

name: Vitamin B1/Thiamine
description: Thiamine (vitamin B1) is a water-soluble vitamin essential for carbohydrate metabolism and neural function.
details: Measured via high-performance liquid chromatography (HPLC) of whole blood or erythrocyte transketolase activity assay. Normal plasma thiamine levels range from 70 to 180 ng/mL. Levels below 50 ng/mL suggest deficiency, which can lead to beriberi, Wernicke encephalopathy, and impaired oxidative metabolism. Therapeutic monitoring often uses erythrocyte transketolase activation coefficient, with values >1.25 indicating deficiency.

name: Vitamin B12/Cobalamin
description: Cobalamin (vitamin B12) is a water-soluble vitamin essential for DNA synthesis, red blood cell formation, and neurological function.
details: Measured via immunoassay or chemiluminescence; serum B12 levels of 200–900 pg/mL are considered normal; levels 150–200 pg/mL are borderline and may warrant further evaluation; <150 pg/mL indicate deficiency with risk of megaloblastic anemia and neuropathy; values >1000 pg/mL often reflect supplementation or certain hematologic disorders. Holotranscobalamin assays can detect deficiency earlier.

name: Vitamin B2/Riboflavin
description: Riboflavin (vitamin B2) is a water-soluble vitamin essential for energy metabolism, redox reactions, and the maintenance of cellular function.
details: Measured via HPLC in serum or plasma; normal plasma riboflavin ranges from 4 to 24 µg/dL (106–638 nmol/L). Levels below 4 µg/dL indicate deficiency with symptoms of ariboflavinosis (cheilosis, glossitis, dermatitis), while levels >24 µg/dL are above optimal and >30 µg/dL suggest excess intake. Riboflavin status can also be assessed by erythrocyte glutathione reductase activation coefficient, with values >1.4 indicating deficiency.

name: Vitamin B3/Niacin
description: Nicotinic acid and nicotinamide form vitamin B3, essential for NAD/NADP synthesis, energy metabolism, and DNA repair.
details: Measured via HPLC in plasma. Reference ranges from Cambridge Biomedical Research Group: 0.50–8.45 µg/mL for individuals ≥10 years; levels <0.50 µg/mL suggest deficiency (risk of pellagra). Nicotinamide concentrations from supplements and diet can reach up to 72.1 µg/mL; therapeutic niacin doses may yield plasma levels >30 µg/mL. Interpretation benefits from concurrent urinary niacin metabolite analysis for status assessment.

name: Vitamin B5/Pantothenic acid
description: Pantothenic acid (vitamin B5) is a water-soluble vitamin essential for coenzyme A synthesis and energy metabolism.
details: Measured via HPLC or microbiological assay in whole blood. Normal whole blood levels are 344–583 µg/L; values below 300 µg/L may suggest deficiency (rare, with symptoms such as fatigue and neuropathy), while levels above 600 µg/L often reflect high supplemental intake; levels >1000 µg/L are uncommon and may indicate excessive supplementation.

name: Vitamin B6/Pyridoxal 5-phosphate
description: Pyridoxal 5'-phosphate (PLP) is the active coenzyme form of vitamin B6, critical for amino acid metabolism, neurotransmitter synthesis, and hemoglobin formation.
details: Measured via HPLC in plasma. Normal PLP concentrations range from 20 to 125 ng/mL; values below 20 ng/mL indicate suboptimal status and risk of deficiency symptoms such as anemia, neuropathy, and seizures. Levels below 5 ng/mL are consistent with overt deficiency. Elevated levels (>150 ng/mL) may result from high-dose supplementation and can lead to sensory neuropathy at very high concentrations.

name: Vitamin B7/Biotin
description: Biotin (vitamin B7) is a water-soluble vitamin that acts as a coenzyme for carboxylase enzymes, essential in fatty acid synthesis, amino acid catabolism, and gluconeogenesis.
details: Measured via immunoassay or mass spectrometry in serum or plasma. Normal serum biotin levels range from 0.2 to 1.0 ng/mL; levels below 0.1 ng/mL suggest deficiency, which can manifest as dermatitis, alopecia, neurological symptoms, and metabolic disturbances. Elevated levels (>2.0 ng/mL) may result from supplementation and are typically not harmful.

name: Vitamin B9/Folic acid
description: Folic acid (vitamin B9) is a water-soluble B vitamin essential for DNA synthesis, repair, and methylation, and red blood cell formation.
details: Measured via immunoassay or microbiological assay. Serum folate levels of 5–20 ng/mL are considered adequate in adults; levels 3–5 ng/mL indicate marginal deficiency and risk of megaloblastic anemia; <3 ng/mL indicate deficiency. RBC folate reflects long-term status, with >140 ng/mL indicating adequate stores. Elevated levels (>25 ng/mL) may result from supplementation; extremely high levels (>60 ng/mL) can mask B12 deficiency.

name: Vitamin D2
description: Vitamin D2 (ergocalciferol) is one form of vitamin D obtained from plant sources and fortified foods; measured as 25-hydroxyvitamin D2 in serum to assess vitamin D status.
details: Measured via immunoassay or liquid chromatography–tandem mass spectrometry (LC-MS/MS). Combined with 25-hydroxyvitamin D3 to form total 25-hydroxyvitamin D, sufficiency is defined as ≥30 ng/mL, insufficiency 20–29 ng/mL, deficiency <20 ng/mL, and risk of toxicity rises at levels >150 ng/mL, which may lead to hypercalcemia and related complications.

name: Vitamin D3
description: Vitamin D3 (cholecalciferol) is produced in the skin upon UV exposure and obtained from animal-based foods; measured as serum 25‑hydroxyvitamin D3 to assess vitamin D status.
details: Measured via immunoassay or LC-MS/MS. Serum 25‑hydroxyvitamin D3 levels ≥30 ng/mL indicate sufficiency; 20–29 ng/mL indicate insufficiency; <20 ng/mL indicate deficiency. Levels >150 ng/mL pose risk of toxicity (hypercalcemia, renal impairment). Total vitamin D status combines D2 and D3 measurements.

name: Vitamin D total
description: Total 25-hydroxyvitamin D measures combined D2 and D3 forms in serum, reflecting overall vitamin D status.
details: Measured via liquid chromatography–tandem mass spectrometry (LC-MS/MS) or immunoassay; total 25-hydroxyvitamin D (D2 + D3) is the best indicator of vitamin D status. Levels ≥30 ng/mL indicate sufficiency; 20–29 ng/mL indicate insufficiency; <20 ng/mL indicate deficiency; >150 ng/mL pose risk of toxicity (hypercalcemia, renal impairment).

name: Vitamin E
description: Vitamin E refers primarily to serum alpha-tocopherol, a lipid-soluble antioxidant protecting cell membranes from oxidative damage.
details: Measured via high-performance liquid chromatography (HPLC) of serum or plasma. Normal alpha-tocopherol levels range from 5 to 18 µg/mL; levels <5 µg/mL suggest deficiency (risk of hemolysis, neuropathy), and levels >20 µg/mL may reflect excess supplementation and can interfere with vitamin K–dependent clotting factors. Critically low (<2 µg/mL) or high (>30 µg/mL) values warrant clinical evaluation.

name: Vitamin K
description: Vitamin K refers to phylloquinone (K1) and menaquinones (K2), essential fat-soluble vitamins required for blood clotting and bone metabolism.
details: Measured via HPLC of plasma phospholipid fraction. Typical serum phylloquinone (K1) levels range from 0.2 to 3.0 ng/mL; levels below 0.1 ng/mL suggest deficiency, leading to impaired gamma-carboxylation of clotting factors, prolonged prothrombin time, and bleeding risk. Levels above 5.0 ng/mL often reflect high dietary or supplemental intake; levels >10 ng/mL are uncommon and may indicate excess supplementation.

name: VO2 Max
description: VO2 Max is the maximal rate of oxygen consumption measured during incremental exercise; it is the gold standard metric for cardiorespiratory fitness.
details: Assessed via graded exercise testing with gas analysis. Higher VO2 Max values indicate superior aerobic endurance and lower cardiovascular risk. Typical ranges vary by age and sex: young adult males (40–50 mL/kg/min), young adult females (30–40 mL/kg/min), with gradual decline of ~10% per decade. Values <20 mL/kg/min denote poor fitness and increased health risk.

name: Zinc
description: Serum zinc reflects the body’s zinc status, essential for enzymatic reactions, immune function, and antioxidant defense. Levels can decrease during acute inflammation.
details: Measured via ICP-MS or atomic absorption spectroscopy in trace-element tubes. Normal adult levels are 10–20 µmol/L; levels below ~8 µmol/L may indicate deficiency (e.g., malabsorption, chronic illness), and levels above ~25 µmol/L suggest excess intake, with toxicity risks rising >40 µmol/L. Interpretation should consider inflammation (CRP) and sample handling to avoid hemolysis :contentReference[oaicite:0]{index=0}.
